subject: RE: [junit] Avoiding Hard coded locations

messageBody:
What we do here is set a system property called "test.data.dir" which is
passed to the JVM running JUnit either via Ant or on the command line as a
-Dtest.data.dir=/path/to/dir. Any test case writer who needs access to the
data dir always knows he can find it by System.getProperty("test.data.dir").

That works for us. Then under the test-data dir, which is in source control
with the source but not mixed in with the source, we have a directory
structure matching the top-levels of the package structure of the code we're
testing. Not the whole structure is reflected -- just what's needed to
distinguish say the jrun.deployment test data from the jrun.ejb.persistence
tests, etc.

Generally, the way many applications get around this problem is to establish
a default conventional location for the directory to load data from, and
then use a system or application level property (registry setting, etc.) to
make it easily customizable. For example:

Web-apps:
WEB-INF/classes
WEB-INF/lib

JVM:
$JDK_HOME/jre/lib/ext

Apache:
htdocs/
cgi-bin/

IIS:
wwwroot/
scripts/

etc.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia
